node.Title: How to write a good introduction
node.Body:
The preamble is the first opening sentences of your article, which are usually in bold. The introduction is your chance to convince the reader in a few seconds that your article is worth reading. It should therefore be short and to the point and preferably evoke emotions.

What do you think is most important, most interesting or surprising in your article? Is there something that evokes emotions in you? Highlight it in the preamble!

Tips for those who want to write a good introduction:

1. Think about what in your article is new, important, surprising or emotional.

2, Now choose ONE of the most interesting things in your text and highlight it in the introduction. You can tell us about the rest further down in the article.

3. Feel free to use strong words or expressions that attract the reader's attention.

4. Keep it short, no more than five sentences.

5. Wash unnecessary words out of your introduction.
node.Summary: Imagine you have three seconds to persuade someone to read your article. What would you then highlight to arouse interest? If you have the answer to that question - then you have also found your entrance!

node.Title: Elevpublicistens ansvar
node.Body:
Mobile Stories har samma värdegrund som skolan. Den vill vi att du ska hålla dig till när du arbetar med vårt verktyg och publicerar dina arbeten på mobilestories.se.
 

Värdegrunden omfattar:

  • människolivets okränkbarhet
  • individens frihet och integritet
  • alla människors lika värde
  • jämställdhet mellan könen
  • solidaritet mellan människor
  1. Det du publicerar på Mobile Stories blir tillgängligt för alla. Genomslagskraften av det du skriver kan vara stor. Även om du väljer att publicera endast på din skola så kan alla läsa eller titta på just din artikel.
  2. Tänk på att det du skriver kan delas och spridas i andra forum. Där kan kommentarer dyka upp. Mobile Stories har inte kommentarsfält på sajten.
  3. När du publicerar artiklar på Mobile Stories så ansvarar du själv för innehållet. Du själv ansvarar alltså för att din artikel inte bryter mot några lagar och regler. Det du skriver får därför inte innehålla t ex förtal, förolämpning, hets mot folkgrupp, sexualiserat våld mot barn eller våldspornografi. Du får inte heller använda material som någon annan har upphovsrätten till utan att den personen har gett sitt tillstånd.                      
  4. Undvik att publicera uppgifter som kan leda till att din uppgiftslämnare får problem. Tänk alltid igenom eventuella konsekvenser för den som gett dig uppgifter eller för personer som berörs i ditt material.
  5. Undvik att publicera material från personer som vill vara anonyma, eftersom det alltid är svårt att garantera en person anonymitet. Om en uppgiftslämnare är anonym är det också svårare för den som tar del av ditt material att granska de källor som används. 

Jag har tagit del av Mobile Stories regler och de lagar som gäller vid publiceringar på nätet.

Grattis! Du är nu elevpublicist och är en del av ett nätverk av unga som skapar genomarbetat innehåll för att inspirera, berätta, förklara, granska och göra skillnad. Lycka till!

node.Title: About cookies
node.Body:
The website mobilestories.se and mobilestories.com uses cookies. According to the law, all visitors to a website that uses cookies must be informed that the website contains cookies, what they are used for, and how to opt out of them.

A cookie is a small text file stored on the visitor's computer and contains information. Cookies are typically used to enhance the website for the visitor.

There are two types of cookies: one type saves a file that remains on the visitor's computer. This file is used, for example, to make it easier for the visitor to use the website according to their preferences and interests. The other type is called a session cookie. It is temporarily stored in the visitor's computer's memory while the visitor is on a webpage. Session cookies disappear when the visitor closes their browser. No personal information, such as email or name, is saved about the visitor.

Both types of cookies are used on the mobilestories.seand mobilestories.com website. When you visit our website, a session cookie is sent between your computer and our web server to facilitate navigation, among other things. Session cookies are also used when you are logged in to mobilestories.se. The cookie disappears when you end your visit.

If you, as a visitor, do not accept that the website uses cookies, you can disable this function through your browser's security settings. You can also set your browser to give you a warning every time the website tries to set a cookie on your computer.

Managing Local Data Storage in Your Browser

You can delete cookies from your browser and device and adjust settings in your browser for whether and how local information is stored. This means that no cookies will be stored, but you may not be able to use certain features on mobilestories.se. Here is information on how to manage cookies in your browser:

  • Chrome (link: https://support.google.com/...)
  • Safari (link: https://support.apple.com/...)
  • Safari on iPhone and iPad (link: https://support.apple.com/sv-se/HT201265)
  • Internet Explorer (link: https://support.microsoft.com/...)
  • Firefox (link: https://support.mozilla.org/...)

node.Title: 3 steps to writing a great lead
node.Body:
A lead is the opening sentences of an article. It should arouse curiosity, draw attention and lead the reader into the article. What do you think is most important, most interesting or surprising in your article? What in the article stirs your emotions? Highlight that in your lead!

3 steps to a great lead:

1. What in your article is new, important, surprising or that evokes emotions in you. Choose ONE of these things and highlight it in the lead. Feel free to use strong words or expressions that attract the reader's attention.

2. Keep it short. A good introduction should ideally be between two and five sentences. Also, wash unnecessary words out of your introduction to make it more to the point!

3. Try it on a friend! Feel free to write a few different versions. Which version piques your friend's interest?

Keep in mind that a good lead can be crucial for you to be able to reach out and have an impact on others. Feel free to think about which leads of the news media attract your attention – and why? Thus, you can improve your sense of what makes a really good lead!

node.Title: Så skriver du en bra ingress
node.Body:
Ingressen är de första inledande meningarna i din artikel, som brukar vara i fetstil. Ingressen är din chans att på några sekunder övertyga läsaren att din artikel är värd att läsa. Den ska därför vara kort och kärnfull och gärna väcka känslor.

Vad tycker du själv är viktigast, mest intressant eller överraskande i din artikel? Finns det något som väcker känslor hos dig? Lyft fram det i ingressen!

Tips till dig som vill skriva en bra ingress:

1. Fundera över vad i din artikel som är nytt, viktigt, överraskande eller som väcker känslor. 

2, Välj nu EN av de mest intressanta sakerna i din text och lyft fram det i ingressen. Resten kan du berätta om längre ner i artikeln. 

3. Använd gärna starka ord eller uttryck, som väcker läsarens uppmärksamhet.

4.  Håll dig kort, max fem meningar. 

5. Tvätta bort onödiga ord ur din ingress. Då blir den mer rapp och kärnfull.
node.Summary: Tänk dig att du har tre sekunder på dig att övertala någon att läsa din artikel. Vad skulle du då lyfta fram för att väcka intresse? Om du har svaret på den frågan – då har du också hittat din ingress!

node.Title: News Article
node.Body:
A NEWS SHOULD BE:

1. True (verified sources).

2. Relevant (important for people to know).

3. New, i.e. something that is not previously generally known.

Mobile Stories template for News Article or Standard Article can also be used for interviews, portraits or simple reports.

Questions to help you get started with your news article:

1. What is “the thing”? Think about what in your article is new, surprising and interesting to your readers. In other words: What is the actual news? Has something happened? New information that has come to light? Or just something that you think more people should know? Maybe you have some happy news to share.

2. Who is the "case"? For an article to touch the reader, it is good to have a "case". A case is the individual person or people affected by a particular decision or otherwise affected by what you are writing about. It could also be someone who has done something good that needs to be highlighted and perhaps inspire others!

3. Who is an expert? Feel free to let an expert on the subject explain and nuance the factual information you present to the reader. An expert can be a researcher, an official or someone else who is specialized in the issue the article is about.

4. Who thinks something? Are there people who have different opinions about what you write about? Let them present their different positions (opinions). If someone is criticized in the text or by the interviewees who speak in the text, the person who is criticized must also be allowed to speak.

5. Who can be held accountable? If you write about something that went wrong, you should let the person responsible speak. Ask critical questions!
node.Summary: In a news article, the reporter must be factual and correct. Any opinions about or analyzes of the news must be expressed through interviewees.

node.Title: Where do I find free images?
node.Body:
Feel free to explore the Creative Commons image license. With it, anyone can license their images, but also audio, music and video, so that others can use them. Read about how Creative Commons works here: http://www.creativecommons.se/om-cc/.

Search for free images here (don´t forget to look carefully at the terms of use): https://search.creativecommons.org/

You can also download images from Pixabay's website. Here are some of the pictures free to publish and distribute online (Note. Choose a picture without a stamp.): https://pixabay.com

Images from Wikipedia can also be free to publish. Under the image you want to use, you will see the symbol for Common Creatives and any special conditions for using the image.

At Wikimedia you will find free Creative Commons images: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:Welcome

The site Moderskeppet.se has tips about more free image sources: http://bit.ly/2nRUlhw

GOOD TO KNOW WHEN PUBLISHING PICTURES ON MOBILE STORIES:

"Portrait" and "landscape" image?  A portrait is higher than it is wide and horizontal is the opposite - wider than high. In Mobile Stories articles, landscape images work best. The introductory image used for the slide show must always be a landscape image.

Don´t forget the caption. Always write a caption, preferably something that is not already in your text. At the end of the caption, type PICTURE: First name Last name (that is, the photographer or illustrator who owns the copyright to the image). Also enter the name of the photographer / illustrator in field number two.

Take many pictures. Then think about which one was the best. Feel free to test on a friend. Look at a lot at other people's pictures and think about whether they are good or not. Choose some really good pictures and think about why you like them. Try to take similar ones yourself.

Dont´t forget the copyright. A photo byline tells you who owns the copyright to the picture. It can be the name of a photographer, illustrator or an agency. If the photo is copyright free, you must look carefully at the terms of use. Make sure the picture also is free for "commercial use". If not, it can´t be published on Mobilestories.se. 

Is the picture true? Keep in mind that images in an article must not be manipulated. Therefore, they must not be changed so they no longer correspond to reality. If you have made an image montage, e.g. if you splice two images together so that they look like one, this must be clearly stated in your caption. 

Last updated 03.11.13

node.Title: How to list sources in an article
node.Body:
The exception is if the text is fiction, ie a short story - here you have greater artistic freedom and can let your imagination flourish. But as soon as you deal with reality, in a news article, an interview or a documentary video, you have to state the sources of the information. In most article types there is also a box where you state the sources you have used and paste in links to the digital sources.

  • Do you want to refer to a text - such as a research report or survey - that someone else has written? Then can refer to this way: Eight out of ten do not know, for example, where to turn if they want to influence a political decision in the municipality, according to a survey conducted by the Agency for Civil Society Affairs, MUCF.
  • If the source is a person you spoke to, use a number line instead, according to this model: - As a news reporter, you must constantly look around in your environment for things that go out of the ordinary, says news reporter Förnamn Efternamn at the newspaper Dagbladet.
  • Also enter the sources in the current text. Example: According to statistics from Statistics Sweden, men have a shorter life expectancy…. "Or" Swedish students have become better at math, according to a survey carried out by Authority XX ". ).
    Finally, enter the names and any links to all your sources in the source box in the Mobile Stories tool.

Peer review

The more eyes and ears that have reviewed your article, video or podcast before publishing, the better. Are there any ambiguities? Is there information that has no specified source? Sources who feel hesitant? Discuss!

Review each other's texts. Let at least two friends go through your article and review the credibility of your sources.
Discuss. By turning and turning each individual case, you get experience that helps you become sharper already in the next task.

By: Jenny Sköld

node.Title: Who can be the source?
node.Body:
Different sources have different levels of credibility. An original source (for example, someone who has experienced something themselves, a research study or an image that has not been manipulated) often has higher credibility than a second-hand source (for example, someone who reproduces what someone else has experienced). Also keep in mind that the more sources that are independent of each other provide consistent information, the stronger the credibility!

Examples of sources:

The experts. If your source is an expert you talk to, for example and a researcher, it should be clear what makes that particular person credible. The expert should have a special knowledge of exactly what he is saying.
Case. The case is an interviewee who is in some way affected by what you write about. It could be someone who has experienced injustice or someone who has done something good and who can inspire others.
The witness. A witness is someone who can confirm what you are writing about. You should preferably collect more than one testimony that indicates that the event that you mention in your article has taken place.
The picture. An image, still image, or moving image that shows an event can also be a source. Keep in mind that images can be manipulated and not always true.
The document. A document can be, for example, a written e-mail, notes from a meeting or a decision from an authority or from the government.
You. Among other things, you yourself become a source when you publish something online.
node.Summary: As a reporter for Mobile Stories, you use many different sources. It can be interviewees who have been involved in something you tell about, researchers and other experts or information from other media.

node.Title: Så anger du källor i en artikel
node.Body:
Undantaget är om texten är skönlitterär, alltså en novell – här har du större konstnärlig frihet och kan låta fantasin blomma. Men så fort du befattar dig med verkligheten, i en nyhetsartikel, en intervju eller en ett dokumentärt videoinslag, så måste du uppge källorna till informationen. I de flesta artikeltyper finns också en box där du uppger de källor du använt och klistrar in länkar till de digitala källorna. 

Så här gör du:

  • Vill du hänvisa till en text – till exempel en forskningsrapport eller undersökning – som någon annan har skrivit? Då kan referera på det här sättet: Åtta av tio vet till exempel inte vart de ska vända sig om de vill påverka ett politiskt beslut i kommunen, enligt en undersökning som gjorts av Myndigheten för civilsamhällesfrågor, MUCF.
  • Om källan är en person som du pratat med använder du i stället ett talstreck, enligt den här modellen: – Som nyhetsreporter gäller att hela tiden leta i sin omgivning efter sådant som går utanför det vanliga, säger nyhetsreporter Förnamn Efternamn på tidningen Dagbladet.
  • Skriv också in källorna i den löpande texten. Exempel: Enligt statistik från SCB har män kortare medellivslängd…. “ eller “Svenska elever har blivit bättre på matte, enligt en kartläggning som Myndigheten XX gjort".  Lägg gärna även in källorna som hyperlänkar i själva texten (det vill säga länka från namnet på källan i din text till den webbsida där du hämtat dina uppgifter).
  • Lägg slutligen in namnen och eventuella länkar till alla dina källor i boxen för källor i Mobile Stories verktyg.
node.Summary: När du publicerar en artikel på Mobile Stories anger du alltid var informationen kommer från i löpande text, eller om du påstår något i en podd eller film.

node.Title: Få koll på olika källor
node.Body:
Som reporter på Mobile Stories använder du förmodligen många olika källor. Det kan vara intervjupersoner som varit med om något som du berättar om, forskare och andra experter eller uppgifter från andra medier. Olika källor har olika hög trovärdighet. En originalkälla (till exempel någon som själv upplevt något, en forskningsstudie eller en bild som inte manipulerats) har ofta högre trovärdighet än en andrahandskälla (till exempel någon som återger vad någon annan upplevt). Tänk också på att ju fler källor som oberoende av varandra ger överenstämmande uppgifter, desto starkare blir trovärdigheten! 

Exempel på källor:

  • Experten. Om din källa är en expert som du pratat med, exempelvis en forskare, ska det framgå vad som gör att just den personen är trovärdig. Experten bör ha en specialkunskap om just det som hen uttalar sig om. 
  • Caset. Caset är en intervjuperson som på något sätt är berörd av det du skriver om. Det kan vara någon som har upplevt en orättvisa eller någon som gjort något bra och som kan inspirera andra.
  • Vittnet. Ett vittne är någon som kan bekräfta det du skriver om Du ska helst samla in fler än ett vittnesmål som pekar på att händelsen som du tar upp i din artikel har ägt rum. 
  • Bilden. En bild, stillbild eller rörlig bild, som visar en händelse kan också vara en källa. Tänk på att bilder kan vara manipulerade och inte alltid sanna. 
  • Dokumentet. Ett dokument kan vara till exempel ett skrivet mejl, anteckningar från ett möte eller ett beslut från en myndighet eller från regeringen. 
  • Du. Du själv blir naturligtvis en källa när du publicerar något på nätet.

node.Title: Metoder för källkritik
node.Body:
Den traditionella källkritiska metoden bygger på kriterierna Äkthet, Tid, Beroende och Tendens. För att få med alla kriterier kan man ställa frågorna Vem? Vad? Varför? När? 

Nätet ställer andra krav på faktagranskaren än till exempel en papperstidning. För att kontrollera uppgifter på nätet bör faktagranskaren inte fastna vid den första hemsidan som dyker upp i sökresultatet utan gå vidare och ta reda på om uppgifterna kan bekräftas på fler websidor och vad andra källor säger om den första websidans trovärdighet. Den som källgranskar på nätet bör alltså ha uppe flera flikar samtidigt för bästa resultat!

Här hittar du fler bra metoder för att granska källor:

  • Skolverkets checklista för källkritik: Skolverket: Kolla källan
  • Myndigheten för samhällsskydd och beredskap: Källkritik
  • Internetstiftelsens metod för källkritik på nätet Internetstiftelsen: Guide för källkritik
node.Summary: Att granska källor är elevpublicistens kanske allra viktigaste uppgift. Den som har fel förlorar sin trovärdighet och riskerar att ge spridning åt rykten, desinformation eller tjäna någon annans kommersiella intressen.

node.Body:
Anna Holmquist, vd och grundare av medieföretaget Gazzine hjälper journalister över hela världen att vässa sina rubriker. I den här videon delar hon med sig av sina bästa tips till dig för att du ska få fler läsare. Missa inte den!

 

Annas viktigaste tips för en riktigt vass rubrik:

  1. Var tydlig! 
  2. Använd gärna en siffra i rubriken!
  3. Inled gärna med ordet "Så..." om det passar (Ex. Så skriver du en fantastisk rubrik")
  4. Använd powerord (Ex. "Unik", "Aktuell", "Spektakulär")
  5. Överraska läsaren!
  6. Undvik att ställ frågor i rubriiken!
  7. Korrläs din rubrik!

node.Body: The network places different demands on the fact-checker than, for example, a printed newspaper. To check information online, the fact checker should not stick to the first website that appears in the search results but go ahead and find out the information can be confirmed on more websites and what other sources say about the credibility of the first website. Anyone who reviews sources online should therefore have several tabs up at the same time for best results!

node.Title: The responsibility of the student reporter
node.Body:
Through it, the media, but also you as a citizen, can examine those in power and make a difference. But freedom of speech also entails responsibility. These are some things we want you to keep in mind.

Mobile Stories has the same values ​​as the school. We want you to stick to these when you work with our tool and publish your work on "All of Sweden's school channel."

The values ​​include:

the inviolability of human life

the freedom and integrity of the individual

the equal value of all human beings

equality between the sexes

solidarity between people

What you publish on Mobile Stories will be available to everyone. The impact of what you write can be great. Even if you choose to publish only at your school, everyone can read or look at your particular article.

Keep in mind that what you write can be shared and spread in other forums. Comments can appear there. Mobile Stories does not have comment fields on the site.

When you publish articles on Mobile Stories, you are responsible for the content. You are therefore responsible for ensuring that your article does not violate any laws and regulations. What you write must therefore not contain, for example, slander, insult, incitement against ethnic groups, sexualized violence against children or violent pornography. You may also not use material that someone else has the copyright to without that person's permission.

Avoid publishing information that could cause your informant problems. Always think through any consequences for the person who gave you information or for people who are mentioned in your material.

Avoid publishing material from people who wish to remain anonymous, as it is always difficult to guarantee a person's anonymity. If an informant is anonymous, it is also more difficult for the person consuming your material to review the sources used.

node.Title: 10 tips for getting your Op-Ed placed
node.Body:
Today, everyone has the opportunity to publish their opinions online. But how do you get people to listen? Anyone who wants to reach out with their message and maybe even change something must spend time on their text.

Kristofer Forssblad Olsson works at the debate editorial office at the newspaper Aftonbladet. He receives a daily stream of emails from people who want to include their debate articles in the newspaper - many are young people. Sometimes it is school classes that submit a joint debate article and sometimes individual students.

- We get a lot of debate articles from young people. They are often about appearance fixation and anorexia, racism, LGBTQ and the environment. These are subjects that engage young people. Stress at school and grades are also common topics.

Anyone who succeeds in arousing Kristofer's interest can suddenly reach over three million readers - there are so many people who go to Aftonbladet.se or read the paper newspaper every day. It can sometimes be quite shocking for the writer.

- We had a woman who ended up on TV4's morning couch after we published an article she wrote about Swedish care. She was probably a little shocked when they called from TV4 and the radio and suddenly she was sitting on the morning couch and talking about this.

Not everyone can come to the morning couch. But by knowing a few tricks, you can get more people to read and can increase their opportunities to influence.

To entice the reader into reading the text, it is important to know what you want to say and to stick to the topic. And feel free to have a personal touch.

 - It is important to arouse interest and be credible. It's good to start with yourself - how would I be interested in this? In newsrooms, the debate editors usually choose the actual title of the submitted debate article, so you don´t have to put so much work into it.

 Then, of course, it is important to keep the reader's interest in the final clip. It can be an advantage to write about an issue or topic that you yourself are passionate about. Then it is easier to write in an engaging way.

If you can check out the points below, there is every possibility that your debate article will end up in the newspaper or be published online.

- If you get into a debate about the problem you are writing about, things can start to happen. Maybe there might even be a change in the law in the long run, which makes society better.

Kristofer's tips: How to reach a wide audience with your opinion piece

Find a topic

1. Pick a current topic. Then there is a greater chance that news media will pick up or publish your opinion piece.

2. Highlight your opinions. Unlike a news article, one's own opinions should be in focus in an opinion piece.

3. Start with yourself. A text that is about something you yourself have thought about or been through automatically becomes more engaging for the reader.

Find the facts

4. Support with facts. Feel free to pick out the facts you should substantiate your argumentation with even before you start writing. Being able to substantiate your claims with facts increases your credibility. If you write that every third student has encountered something, you must be able to prove it with facts.

5. Check your sources. Feel free to use Mobile Stories' Journalist's guide for source criticism "Also link to the sources if possible, preferably in the running text so it is easy for the reader to check. Anyone who does not know their sources loses their credibility and ability to really influence.

Engage the reader

6. Put some effort into the introduction. Your headline and lead are crucial for making people want to read your article. Start with yourself - would you yourself be interested in reading more?

7. Start with what is most important. Elaborate introductions such as "My name is xx ..." or "We have been commissioned to ...." should be avoided. Push the message instead.

8. Stick to the common thread. Think first: What do I want to say? Then stick to your most important message and peel away any extravagance. Between 2500 and 4000 characters including spaces are usually appropriate.

9.  Avoid language that is too complicated . Clarity is more important than using complicated words or "bureaucratic Swedish".

What do you want to happen?

10. Who has the opportunity to do something about the problem you describe in your text? An opinion piece article should be happy to describe a problem and provide solutions or suggestions for how the situation can be improved.

By: Jenny Sköld

Last updated 03.10.22

When you publish articles on Mobile Stories, you are responsible for the content. You are therefore responsible for ensuring that your article does not violate any laws and regulations. What you write must therefore not contain, for example, slander, insult, incitement against ethnic groups, sexualized violence against children or violent pornography. You may also not use material that someone else has the copyright to without that person's permission.

Avoid publishing information that could cause your informant problems. Always think through any consequences for the person who gave you information or for people who are mentioned in your material.

Avoid publishing material from people who wish to remain anonymous, as it is always difficult to guarantee a person's anonymity. If an informant is anonymous, it is also more difficult for the person consuming your material to review the sources used.

node.Title: The Mobile Stories Code of Ethics
node.Body:
Take your time and read the code thoroughly. Why not post it on the classroom wall? Eventually it will enter your bloodstream.

The Mobile Stories Code of Ethics is inspired by the Swedish Medias' Code of Ethics, but has been adapted to better suit Mobile Stories student reporters.

Stick to the truth:

Avoid spreading rumors and misinformation. The Mobile Stories publicists must, as far as possible, ensure that all the facts in a story are correct. This also applies to images, which must not be distorted by image editing programs such as Photoshop. Keep in mind that the truth requirement applies to text, images, videos and podcasts.

Be critical of your sources. Check facts as carefully as possible, even those that have already been published elsewhere. If possible, go to the original source.

Clearly distinguish between opinions and facts. It should be clear to the reader, viewer or listener what is factual reporting and what is an opinion or comment. This is most easily achieved by keeping the text of an article neutral, while the interviewees' opinions may appear in their quotes. In a chronicle or debate article, on the other hand, it is always the writer's own opinions that emerge. But it is still important to support their arguments with credible sources.

(Does not apply to chronicles and debate articles) Let both sides speak. If someone is criticized in an article, that person must be allowed to respond to the criticism. If an opinion is given, it is important to also give space to the other side of the issue.

Keep to what you promise in your headline. The title should always have coverage in the text, film or podcast.

Don´t advertise. Your articles should not be published to benefit any person or company financially.

Respect the privacy of others:

Don´t publish things about others that you would not want anyone else to publish about yourself. Also keep in mind that different people have different boundaries for what is perceived as offensive.

Exception: If the person is public and has a lot of power, such as a politician, you have more freedom to criticize. Criticizing an international celebrity, for example, is also a less sensitive matter than criticizing an individual in your immediate environment.

Always ask those in the picture if they are okay with using their image. The exception is if you are in a public place - a square, a shopping street, a festival or a trade fair - where there are many people. Think about whether you yourself would like to be in the picture or in the film and in the context in which you want to publish it.

Don´t emphasize a person's sexual orientation, religious identity or ethnic origin unless relevant.

Let the interviewees review their quotes - if they ask for it. Always change the text if something is wrong.

Take care of your sources - if the sources are people. NEVER publish information that could cause your informant to get into trouble. Think about what consequences publication could have for your interviewees before you publish.

Show special consideration if you take pictures or conduct interviews in connection with accidents or crimes. Don´t interview people who are in shock. Don´t photograph injured people. Keep the discussion alive about codes of conduct in meetings with others in your role as student publicists.

Protect copyright:

Never post pictures that you are not sure you can use. If you have been given permission, don´t forget to print the author's byline next to the image, film or audio clip.

node.Title: The profile
node.Body:
The article is about the person being interviewed and can include both the journalist's questions and the person's answers. Sometimes there is also a fact box about the person, next to the text. In the profile, the journalist tries to get the readers as close to a certain person as possible, and the text is therefore much more personal than the news article or even the report.

At the same time, one must not forget that even a profile is a factual text. The interviews are there to make room for the person you are writing about to give his or her view [A13] on things, but it must always be backed up with the usual fact-checking and source criticism. Therefore, it is also very important to do  proper research and a background check, preferably before the interview. This makes it easier to ask questions, including follow-up questions and decide if the person is remembering incorrectly or distorting the truth.

Since a profile often comes quite close to the person, the journalist must handle the text with great consideration and respect for the integrity of the person being portrayed. If, for example, you have found something disrespectful or negative in your research and want to include it in the text, the person must be informed in connection with the interview. As it is a factual text, space should be given for the person to respond to the negative content and give their view on the matter.

The profile is otherwise structured in the same way as other factual texts, with a title, introduction, body text and captions. The difference is the personal angle and that your quote to a greater extent, reflects what someone says. Don´t forget to try to answer the six journalistic questions: where, when, how, who, what and why.

The title, as always, must be interesting and enticing to read, but at the same time must be true and agree with the text in general. You can try to find a title that summarizes the entire text but also indicates the personal tone.

Example: From Division 3 to Elitettan: despite serious illness, Lotta lifted the team

The lead can also be used for personal portraits, it should introduce the text and should be short. Since the text will focus on one person, the lead should do the same. Feel free to answer any of the journalistic questions in the preface, and try to include a quote.

Example: In just three years, coach Lotta Stenhård has lifted Trädgården BK from a football team facing oblivion to a success story heading for the Allsvenskan. But Lotta is not content with that.

- We will join the Champions League, and win, says the confident coach. But that confidence is new to Lotta, who has had to work hard to get ahead.

The body text of a profile naturally focuses on the person the text is about. Therefore, the text usually contains many more quotes than other texts. Usually, the journalist's questions are also printed, so that the text becomes almost like a conversation. But it may also not be just a narrative text. Since the text must be based on facts, which the journalist has reviewed and read before the interview, there must be space for these facts too. It is with facts that the journalist takes the story forward, and with interviews that one gives explanations and descriptions.

Example: When Lotta Stenhård was recruited to Trädgården BK, the team had played in division 3 for four years, and had even been close to being relegated from the division. After just one year, the new coach had not only lifted the team, but also moved them up to division 2. But the success was far from certain:

- We suffered several injuries that year; in particular Jenny's ligament injury made our defense weak. In the end, it was only by one point that we succeeded in moving up. It was a nervous autumn, says Lotta who is now smiling at it. It was also the same autumn that she received the news of her illness.

- I would not wish that on anyone.

A good way to give a more nuanced picture of the person to be portrayed is to also interview other people nearby, such as colleagues, family and friends. As a journalist, it is important to respect the integrity of and show consideration for the main character. It may happen that the person to be portrayed must be allowed to comment on something that has been said about him. However, it is always the journalist who decides on the final text and is responsible for it.

It is easy for the journalist to fall into the trap of starting to write about himself instead of the person to be portrayed. Pieces that are about how the journalist felt during the interview, or his own experiences don´t belong in a text that is about someone else. Of course, the journalist can be included in the text, but only to a limited extent.

Intermediate headings also work in personal portraits but may not be as necessary as in other factual texts. However, it can be a good idea to use them, as mellisar lighten up the printed text which becomes more airy and easier to read. They can also help the reader to orient themselves in the text and encourage further reading.

Captions are also used in personal portraits, as well as in other journalistic texts. As usual, they should not only reproduce what we see in the picture, but should add some information. Since the personal portrait is intended to give the reader a closer picture and understanding of someone. A quote or a descriptive explanation can be used as a caption.

Example: (Picture of football coach Lotta Stenhård looking out the office window.)

- We will play against the best in Europe, Lotta says firmly.

The fact box is a good way to gather information and facts about the person you are portraying, without weighing down the body text too much. In a delimited box, you can state things that are important for the personal portrait such as background, education, profession. However, more personal things such as taste in music, favorite food and where the person prefers to holiday can also be included in a fact box.

The ending of a profile can be given a slightly more personal feeling that has the same style as the rest of the text. The person you write about may end up thinking about the future in a quote.

- You have to look ahead, says Lotta, and now that I am healthy again, the focus will be on winning the Allsvenskan.

The text is taken from the Media Compass and the Swedish Media Council's joint material The Publicist Guide.

node.Title: Feature story
node.Body:
In a feature story, there is room for a colorful language and large pictures. The author must bring the reader to the scene. You do this by opening your senses. How does it smell? How does that sound? How do people behave at the scene?

 

In a feature story, the text may be a little longer than in the other story templates. 3000 - 7000 characters, including spaces, are usually appropriate. You should have two large images, preferably one or more small ones and maybe an audio file or a video clip. It is also possible to include a slideshow if you have many good pictures to choose from. The audio file should be uploaded to SoundCloud, the video clip at Vimeo or YouTube. Then the embedded link is cut into the “Embedded material” box. Then go to the “Body text” box, place the cursor where you want the clip to be shown and select your clip from the drop-down menu. A code will appear in your text field. It is only when you make a preview of your story that you will see what the embedded clip looks like in your piece.

 

NOTES ON HOW TO MAKE A GREAT FEATURE STORY:

 

  •  Bring the reader to the place. Describe environments, people, scents and sounds.

 

  •  Avoid using the word "I" in the text. It can easily get in the way of the reader's own experience.

 

  • Start by describing something that happens or use an interesting or catchy quote. That will capture the reader's interest.

 

Key components of a feature story:

 

Heading. The headline does not have to focus so much on what has happened as if you had written a news story.

 

Lead. The lead paragraph is the first lines of a story. It should describe what the story is about, but not reveal too much. It should lead the reader into the text. On the Mobile Stories' site, the lead also appears on the front page under the heading.

 

Body text. Feel free to alternate shorter and longer sentences and facts with environmental descriptions. Let the reader "be with" the place you are writing about. How does it look? How does it smell? Feel free to describe the interviewees. How do they move when they talk? What are they wearing? Weave in facts that give weight to the text.

 

Text length: A report must be at least 3000 characters including spaces.

 

Feature story Images. Invest in the pictures. Your feature story will be read more if you take some extra time to about how you can get really good pictures. If possible, make sure that there are pictures of all interviewees, preferably in the environment that the story is about. Pictures of details can be a way to take the story forward. A detail can be, for example, an object that says something about a person in the report or about the topic that is handled. You need to upload an image in the box "Front page image". Also add an image to "Slideshow image for front page". It can be the same image you used in "Front page image".

 

Tags. Choose at least one word that suits your topic. Tags make your story easier to find on the internet.

 

OPTIONALLY

 

Facts. Highlight facts or tips to the reader. They can be inserted as an image in the text.

 

Statistics. Are there any statistics that can back up your story? They can be inserted as an image in the text.

 

Video or audio clips. These should add something to your story. For example, you could use a short clip in which someone shows or tells something.

 

How to report sources in a feature story

 

When you publish a story on Mobilestories.se, you must always tell the reader where the information comes from. You do this in the current text (see below) and in the field for sources.

 

Do you want to refer to a research report, book or survey? Act as in the following example: “Eight out of ten don´t know where to turn if they want to influence a political decision in the municipality, according to a survey conducted by the Agency for Civil Society Affairs, MUCF.”

If the source is someone you´ve interviewed, use a dash instead, according to this model: - As a news reporter, you must always be attentive to things that look out of the ordinary, says news reporter John Doe at the newspaper Daily News.

Example: “According to statistics from SCB, men have a shorter life expectancy…. “[A11]  or “Swedish students have improved in math, according to a survey conducted by Authority XX”. You can also use the hyperlink function to guide your reader to the digital web page where you retrieved your information. Finally, enter the links to all your sources in the box “Sources”.

node.Body:
For a podcast story, in addition to the audio file from SoundCloud, only a title, an introduction and an image are needed. You should upload the audio file in SoundCloud and then cut in the embedded link in the "Embedded material" box. Write a headline on your clip. Then go to the "Body text" box, place the cursor where you want the audio clip to be displayed and select a title. A code will appear in your text field. When you create a new preview, you will see how the clip will appear in the text when the story is published.

 

What your podcast story should contain:

 

Audio. The embedded code from your audio file on SoundCloud.

 

Heading. This should make others want to listen to your podcast. What was the most remarkable or interesting quote in your podcast? Use that as a headline if you want. 

 

Lead. Your lead should summarize what the podcast is about and entice the listener. What would make you want to listen to it?

 

Picture. You can possibly take a picture of the podcast participants, or use a picture that somehow relates to the topic that is discussed in your podcast. Upload it in the box “main image”. You can add the same image in "Front page slide show".

 

Caption. Are the podcast participants in the picture? If so, don´t forget to add their names in the caption. Also describe what is discussed in the podcast in the caption. Take the opportunity to add information that is not already in the introduction and title. Don´t forget to write the name of the person or organization that owns the copyright to the image (usually the person who took the picture).

 

Tags. Choose at least one tag that fits your topic.

 

How to present your sources in a podcast story:

 

If facts are presented in the podcast, it is important your listeners clearly understand where the information comes from. Someone has to give this information in the recording, either at the end of the recording or as soon as someone states something.

Example: “According to statistics from SCB, women live longer than men…." or "Swedish students have become better at math, according to a survey conducted by Authority XX”.

Also add the links to all digital sources in the box “Sources”, which can be found in all story templates.
node.Summary:
For a podcast story, in addition to the audio file from SoundCloud, only a title, an introduction and an image are needed. You should upload the audio file in SoundCloud and then cut in the embedded link in the "Embedded material" box. Write a headline on your clip. Then go to the "Body text" box, place the cursor where you want the audio clip to be displayed and select a title. A code will appear in your text field. When you create a new preview, you will see how the clip will appear in the text when the story is published.

 

What your podcast story should contain:

 

Audio. The embedded code from your audio file on SoundCloud.

 

Heading. This should make others want to listen to your podcast. What was the most remarkable or interesting quote in your podcast? Use that as a headline if you want.

node.Title: Opinion piece
node.Body:
Writing an opinion piece is a way to influence and participate in the public debate. Unlike in a news story, you should highlight your own opinions and use arguments to convince others. Try to find at least three arguments that strengthen your stance. Don´t forget to substantiate your arguments with facts - it makes your piece more credible.

 

TO THINK ABOUT IN AN OPINION PIECE

 

Heading. Remember that the headline should arouse the reader's curiosity. The headline must say something about the content of your piece. 

 

Text. Read more about the structure of the text below.

 

Text length. An opinion piece on Mobile Stories should be at least 1500 characters including spaces and preferably no longer than 4000 characters including spaces.

 

Main image. The main image ends up on the front page of the site where you choose to publish your piece. It will also be featured as the top image in your piece, above your headline. You can use the same image as in "First page slide show"

 

Tags. Choose at least one tag that fits your topic.

 

How to build an opinion piece:

 

This is how a debate opinion piece is usually structured: 1. Your thesis. 2. Three arguments supported by facts. 3. Your call to someone who has the power to make a difference.[A10] 

 

1. Your test. Begin by telling the reader what question you intend to write about. Highlight your opinion.

 

2. Argue for your cause. Find out what different positions (opinions) there are on the issue. Address them in your opinion piece. Use some arguments, preferably three, that strengthen your thesis. It is important for credibility to anchor your arguments in facts: are there surveys or statistics that strengthen your arguments? Refer to them in your text. Don´t forget to link so that the reader can check that what you are writing is correct.

 

3. Who should act? Also think about who is responsible for the problem you describe in your text. Who has the power to change what you think is wrong? A politician? Other young people? At the end of the opinion piece, an invitation to the person or persons may be effective. What do you want them to do?

 

How to refer to your sources in an opinion piece:

 

If you want to be taken seriously, it is important to always present the sources of the facts you use in your opinion piece. Here's how:

 

• Do you want to refer to a text - for example a research report or survey - that someone else has written? Then you can refer to it this way: “Eight out of ten people don´t know where to turn if they want to influence a political decision in the municipality, according to a survey conducted by the Agency for Civil Society Affairs, MUCF.” 

• Also enter the sources in the current text. Example: “According to statistics from Statistics Sweden, men have a shorter life expectancy…. " or "Swedish students have become better at math, according to a survey conducted by Authority XX”.

• Also add the links to all your sources in the box “Sources”, available in all story templates.

node.Title: Chronicle
node.Body:
TO THINK ABOUT IN A CHRONICLE:

 

Heading. The headline should be interesting and should get people to click and read your story. At the same time, the reader must not feel cheated by the headline.

Picture. Use a picture of yourself in the chronicle - a photo or illustration (a selfie or a cartoon self-portrait works fine).

Text length: At least 1,500 and no longer than 4,000 characters, spaces included.

Tags. Choose at least one word that fits your story. This will make it easier for others to find your story on the internet. What words do you think people you want to find the story would use in the search engine field? Feel free to use these keywords as tags.

 

How to present sources in a chronicle:

 

Of course, if you are writing about your own experience, you don´t have to refer to any source in the text (but feel free to add your own name in the "Sources" box). However, if you are writing about a survey or have other factual information you must report to your readers where you obtained the information. Act like this:

 

• Have you taken your information from a text that someone else has written - for example and research report or survey? Then it can be written in this way: “Eight out of ten people don´t know where to turn if they want to influence a political decision in the municipality, according to a survey from the Agency for Civil Society Affairs, MUCF”.

• A source reference can also look like this: “According to statistics from Statistics Sweden, the average life expectancy is short…. " Or “Swedish students have improved their math skills, according to a survey conducted by Authority XX”.

• Add the links to all your sources in the "Sources" box, which is available in all story templates.
node.Summary: A chronicle is a personal story, based on one's own experiences. Take the chance to write about a topic that feels relevant, either at school or in the public debate. The chronicle will be best if you write about something that really matters to you.

node.Title: Gallery
node.Body:
TO THINK ABOUT IN A SLIDESHOW STORY

 

Heading. Choose a headline that makes the reader want to look at the pictures, rather than one that describes what the pictures show.

 

Main image. This image is used on the first page of your site on Mobilestories.se. 

 

At least three good photos. The images must be in the same format, i.e. "portrait" or "landscape". 

 

Lead. Arouse interest in the pictures with two or three sentences. Keep in mind that the lead is also used as the first page text.

 

Captions. Don´t forget the names of people featured in the pictures. Write something that adds information for the reader. Finish your caption by printing out who owns the copyright to the image. Write PHOTO: The name of the photographer or illustrator.

 

Tags. Choose at least one tag that fits your topic.
node.Summary: A slideshow is a series of photos or drawn images. Has the class had an exhibition? Have you created a comic strip or do you want to tell a story about something with images alone? Don´t forget to add captions.

node.Title: The media ethic guidelines
node.Body:
Provide accurate news. Be critical of news sources and check your facts as carefully as circumstances allow. Be clear about what are facts and what are someone's comments.

 

Let people reply when they are criticized. [A9] Incorrect information must be corrected. Give people the opportunity to respond without delay to allegations concerning them.

 

Respect privacy. Refrain from publications that violate people's privacy. Avoid writing about suicide or suicide attempts. Show respect for relatives of crime and accident victims. Don´t emphasize a person's ethnic origin, gender, nationality, profession, political affiliation, religious beliefs or sexual orientation if it is irrelevant or disrespectful in the context.

 

Be careful with editing the images. The press ethics rules also apply to images. Image editing or retouching must not be designed to deceive the reader. If the image has been altered by editing or retouching, it must be specified.

 

Hear both sides. People who are criticized in fact-reporting parts of your story must be given the opportunity to respond to the criticism. Strive to reproduce the positions of all parties in relation to the topic in question.

 

Remember that a criminal suspect must always be considered innocent unless there is a conviction.

 

Be careful with name publications. Avoid publishing names if it might be harmful and there is no obvious public interest. Think about what consequences publication of a name might have for the person concerned, but also for the relatives of the persons concerned. Keep in mind that information about, for example, occupation, age, gender or nationality can also lead to a person in your story being identified.

Source: Media Opinion Board

node.Title: Video
node.Body:
Enter the embedded code (Embedded code) in the "Embedded material" box. Then go to the "Body text" box and place the cursor where you want the movie to be visible. Select your item in the drop-down list above the text field. A code will appear in your text field. When you then create a new preview, you see how the movie will appear in your text.

 

Required elements in a video story:

 

Embedded item. An embedded video that you uploaded to Vimeo or YouTube [A8] (these services work best on Mobilestories.se).

Heading. Say something interesting in your headline, something that will make others want to watch your clip.

Lead. What is your video about? Why should other people watch it? Describe it and make the audience curious.

Picture. You can, for example, use a picture of those who are producing the video, maybe “in action”, shooting the video. Otherwise, a screenshot from the video may work

Caption. Use the caption to say something other than what is already in the preface and title. Don´t forget to write who is in the picture.

Tags. Choose at least one tag that fits the topic of your story.

 

How to present your sources in a video story:

 

If your video is a documentary, i.e. it depicts reality, it is important that you tell your audience where you obtained the facts presented in your video. If you or someone else claims something in the clip, then you or the person talking in the video must say where the information comes from. If there is information in the video, you also need to list your sources in the “Sources” box, included in all story templates.
node.Summary: The video story requires the embedded video link, a heading, a lead paragraph and an image.

node.Title: Review
node.Body:
Anything can be reviewed. A review describes both the downsides and the upsides of the subject, and the purpose is to guide others. Is it worth spending time reading a particular book? Is the new computer game worth the money? How well does a certain film perform compared to other films? Etc.

 

TO THINK ABOUT IN A REVIEW:

 

Heading. The headline can say something about what you think of what you are reviewing, such as "An application that makes life easier" or "Thumbs down for the new Netflix series".

 

Image. If you don´t want to create your own photos or illustrate your story with a drawing, there are sometimes free so-called press pictures to download from the press department on the website behind the service or product you are reviewing. These may be used in reviews. Also add an image in "Slideshow image". Here you can use the same image as in the box "Puff image".

 

Lead. The lead paragraph should summarize the story [A6] [JS7] and entice the reader to keep reading.

 

Body text. In the body text, you describe what you are reviewing and your own experience of it.

 

Facts. It is important to include facts in your review, such as the name of what you are reviewing, who features in it, the authors (i.e. those who created for example the film, computer game or music), where it is available for purchase, and so on.

 

Grade. Rate what you are reviewing on a scale between one and five. 

 

Text length. A review should be at least 1,500 and preferably no longer than 3,500 characters, spaces included.

 

Tags. Choose at least one word that you think fits your story.

 

OPTIONALLY

 

You can choose to add a slide show or an embedded video or audio clip to the "Embedded Material" box.
node.Summary: In a review, the author describes a service, product or cultural experience. The review can be about a book, a Netflix movie or a concert, a computer game, an app or a YouTube clip.

node.Title: Images
node.Body:
The best thing is to create your own images – by illustrating, drawing or taking photos (you can use your cell phone camera). Then you know for sure that you have the copyright to your content. Those interviewed in the text should also be pictured in the story - preferably in the environment or situation described in the story. If, for example, you do a story about a chef, it is good if the person wears their chef's hat and if she or he is doing something in the restaurant kitchen in the picture. Then readers immediately understand what the story is about. Don´t forget to include the names of the pictured persons in the caption. 

Don’t forget:

Take many pictures and then choose your favorites. Try taking photos of a friend before you do the interview. Try different angles, close ups and with different kinds of backgrounds. Look at a lot of other people's pictures and reflect on whether they are good or not. Choose some really good pictures and think about why you like them. Try to take similar ones yourself.

How large should the image be? The feature story images that will be featured at the top and bottom of the published story, should preferably be 35 cm wide and 72 dpi.

"Portrait" and "landscape" image? A vertical image is higher than it is wide, and horizontal is the opposite - wider than it is high. On Mobilestories.se horizontal photos will work better.

Don´t forget the caption. Always write a caption in the caption field below the image. The caption should preferably give readers additional information that is not found elsewhere in the story. If the image features people, their names should preferably be included in the caption.

 

A photo byline says who took or drew the picture. If you have found the image on the internet, it is very important that you thoroughly read the terms of use, where it is stated whether you are allowed to use the image and if so, in what context. Even if the pictures are free, it is important to write who took or owns the picture. Click here (link) to learn more about copyright.

 

Is the picture true? Keep in mind that images in a story must not be manipulated, so that people are fooled by it. It must therefore not be changed so that it no longer corresponds to reality. If you have changed the image in, for example, an image editing program, you must clearly state this in your caption.

 

Catch your audience. Here you can read about how you can use the "golden section" to compose a really good picture.

node.Title: Embed a clip
node.Body:
You can easily embed video or audio clips in your story by using "Embedded" codes from YouTube, Vimeo or SoundCloud:

1. Publish your video or audio clip to Vimeo, YouTube or SoundCloud. These services work best with Mobilestories.se.

2. Upload the "Embedded" code for your video or audio clip (see step-by-step instructions below). Copy the code and paste it in the box "Embedded material".

3. Create a title for your clip. Save.

4. Go to the "Body text" box. Place the cursor in your text where you want the clip to show.

5. Select your item in the "Embedded Material" drop-down menu. The embedded item is now visible as a code in your text field.

6. Create a preview to see what your video or sound clip will look like in your published story.

... from YouTube:

Click "Embed" below the video. Then copy the link and paste it into your story.

.. from Vimeo:

Click the "Share" button.

Then copy the link under "Embed" and paste it into your story.

... from SoundCloud:

Click the "Share" button.

Click "Embed". Then copy the link and paste it into the story.

node.Title: Så gör du en bra intervju
node.Body:
Intervjun går att göra via ett digitalt möte (som Zoom, Skype eller Google Hangout), via mejl eller telefon. Det roligaste och ofta bästa sättet är att träffa personen på riktigt! Det gör intervjun mer "levande". 

För att göra en bra intervju krävs modet att ta kontakt med någon som man kanske inte känner, ibland också en del envishet för att nå fram till rätt person och få den att ställa upp. Under själva intervjun är det viktigt att lyssna och ställa följdfrågor. Att intervjua någon på ett respektfullt sätt är dessutom ett utmärkt sätt att få fler kontakter, kanske inom ett område som du själv är nyfiken på. Man vet aldrig vad ett möte kan leda till – en praktikplats? En vänskap? Ett nytt perspektiv på något? Att förstå vad personen säger och ställa bra följdfrågor för att få personen att utveckla eller förklara kräver att du är påläst och har kunskap om ämnet. 

Intervjun kan delas upp i tre steg:

Förberedelse. 
1. Läs på om ämnet
2. Ta fram frågor. Tänk på att du ska få svar på frågorna Hur? Vem? Vad? och Varför?
3. Förbered tekniken (kolla inspelningsfunktionen på mobilen om du ska spela in samtalet till exempel).
4. Ta kontakt med intervjupersonen – via till exempel mejl, sociala medier eller telefon.

Den första kontakten med intervjupersonen kan ske via mejl eller telefon, lite beroende på vilka kontaktuppgifter du kan få tag på. Lättast brukar vara att leta på hemsidan till den organisation där personen arbetar. Att ringa till någons privata telefonnummer kan vara lite känsligt, om du inte känner personen sedan tidigare. 

Öva gärna i ett rollspel på att presentera er för att öka chansen att få intervjupersonerna att ställa upp. Detta är något journalisten Björn af Kleen är bra på. Läs gärna artikeln "Så får du intervjupersonen att ställa upp".

Genomförande
1. Telefon, digitalt, mejl eller fysiskt
2. Spela in citaten om du behöver skriva ut dem senare (men fråga först intervjupersonen!)
3. Glöm inte följdfrågor! Exempel på följdfrågor är "Varför då"?", "Berätta mer!", "Hur menar du då?" och "Kan du utveckla det?". 
4. Ta en bra bild, alternativt fråga om intervjupersonen kan skicka en. I så fall, var noga med att fråga om vem som tagit den. Om du gör intervjun via exempelvis Skype – fotografera skärmen med mobilen – men glöm inte att fråga först!
5. Fråga om personen vill se citaten! Bestäm hur detta ska gå till. Ska du mejla? Se då till att du har personens mejladress.

Det kan vara svårt att ställa frågor, lyssna på svaren och dessutom anteckna samtidigt. Ett sätt att komma ihåg intervjupersonens svar är att använda en mobiltelefon med inspelningsfunktion och kanske samtidigt skriva ned stödanteckningar under mötet. Väl hemma kan citaten skrivas ut i lugn och ro. Se till att först fråga intervjupersonen om det känns okej att bli inspelad! Annars får du försöka klara dig med anteckningar.

Om intervjun sker på video eller i en podd är det bra att ha ett färdigt manus innan som stöd.

Efterarbete och publicering
1. Bearbeta text/ljud/film, glöm inte namn på upphovsperson för eventuell bild, film, ljud.
2. Låt intervjupersonen se sina citat – om de är i skriven form! Det är viktigt att intervjupersonen bara korrigerar sina egna citat och inte går in och ändrar i den övriga texten – om det inte är rena faktafel. Det är alltid den som skriver artikeln som bestämmer över sin text. 
3. Använd talstreck (—) när du skriver ut intervjupersonens svar.

Om du ska skriva ner citaten och använda i en artikel är det bra om svaren känns levande, så behåll gärna en del av talspråket. Men tänk på att det måste bli lätt att begripa för läsaren. 

Om intervjun är gjord i en podd eller video kan materialet behöva redigeras och klippas. Det är då viktigt att innebörden i det någon sagt inte ändras eller att det klipps in i ett helt nytt sammanhang.

node.Title: Upphovsrätt på nätet – så funkar det
node.Body:
Här är expertens svar på några av de vanligaste frågor som vi på Mobile Stories får om upphovsrätt.

Catharina Ekdahl är jurist på Patent- och registreringsverket, PRV, och är expert på upphovsrätt. Hon projektleder också sajten Upphovsrättsskolan.se, som riktar sig till lärare och elever som vill lära sig mer om hur bild, text och ljud kan användas på nätet utan att upphovsrätten kränks. De flesta frågor om upphovsrätt som vi på Mobile Stories får handlar om bild och rörligt material. Men det finns naturligtvis också regler när det gäller ljud och text – läs mer om detta på Patent- och registreringsverkets sajt Upphovsrättsskolan.se!

Varför kan jag inte använda bilder som ändå redan finns öppet publicerade på nätet?

– Om du vill använda bilder som någon annan har skapat beror det ju på att du antingen inte vill/kan använda en bild du tagit själv eller att bilden du hittat passar perfekt till din artikel. Oavsett vad drar du nytta av det som någon annan har skapat. Ställ dig sedan frågan ”skulle jag vilja att någon annan använde mina bilder utan att jag blev tillfrågad först?”. Om du svarar nej på den frågan, har du förstått vitsen med upphovsrätt. Om du kanske svarar ja istället, ska du veta att det är upp till varje person som skapar ett verk att själv bestämma var gränsen går. Det som kanske skulle vara okej för dig, behöver inte vara okej för någon annan.

Är allt som skapas också upphovsrättsligt skyddat?

- Faktum är att mycket av det som skapas kan vara upphovsrättsligt skyddade verk, om det inte enbart handlar om idéer eller faktauppgifter. För att något ska vara skyddat som verk krävs det att det är originellt och personligt utformat, dvs. att det har ”verkshöjd”. I ett par av de domar som kommer från svenska domstolar framgår det att nivån på originaliteten kan vara ganska låg. Personligt utformat är nog det mesta som skapas, oavsett det handlar om konst, texter eller musik. Det innebär att det allra mesta som är konstnärligt eller litterärt skapat material också är skyddat av upphovsrätt.

Vilka är de vanligaste missuppfattningarna om upphovsrätt?

- Att upphovsrätten bara handlar om pengar. Visst är det så att det finns ett ekonomiskt värde i exempelvis filmer, musik och bilder. Men, mycket av upphovsrättens värde handlar även om att som enskild skapare bli erkänd för det man har gjort eller att slippa hitta sitt verk i ett kränkande sammanhang. Sedan är det inte mer än rätt att den som har lagt ner en massa tid på att skriva en bok, komponera eller spela in musik, producera en film eller måla en tavla också ska kunna få betalt när någon annan vill använda det. Om man som användare inte är beredd på det finns ju alltid möjligheten att skapa något eget istället.

Hur kan jag vara helt säker på att jag får använda en bild i en artikel på exempelvis Mobile Stories?

– Bästa sättet är att ta kontakt med den som har tagit bilden och få tillstånd. Fotografens namn ska nämligen alltid finns nämnd i samband med bilden och sedan kan du söka på namnet på nätet för att hitta en kontaktuppgift. Du kan också vända dig till någon av de organisationer som företräder upphovspersoner. På bildområdet heter organisationen www.bildupphovsratt.se. Ett annat sätt är att använda bilder som ligger på nätet med öppen licens, s k Creative Commons-licenser. Sök på ”CC Search” så hittar du en massa bilder som människor har skapat som kan användas på det sätt som CC-licensen visar. Läs gärna med om CC-licenser på www.creativecommons.se/om-cc/licenserna/

Får jag lov att bädda in Youtube-klipp i min artikel som publiceras på nätet?

– I användarvillkoren som gäller på Youtube kan det finnas begränsning för hur videoklippen får användas. Ett sätt som du nästan alltid kan använda, utan att du behöver få tillstånd från den som har skapat klippet är att lägga en hyperlänk till klippet istället. Avstå alltså ifrån att bädda in klippet och lägg en öppen länk, så att den som läser din artikel tydligt uppfattar att klippet ligger på en annan sida än den där din artikel är publicerad.

Får jag använda skärmdumpar från Youtube?

– Att göra en skärmdump från ett videoklipp är egentligen samma sak som att ta en bildruta ur klippet och använda. Eftersom användarvillkoren på Youtube kanske hindrar dig från att använda ett videoklipp utan att du först har fått tillstånd, kan det finnas anledning att vara försiktig med det eller försöka få ett tillstånd. Kanske är ett alternativ att istället lägga in en hyperlänk till videoklippet på det sätt som jag föreslagit tidigare. Om det då automatiskt dyker upp en skärmdump på klippet genom länken du lagt, kan du nog däremot utgå ifrån att det är okej.

Om jag gör en filmrecension – får jag använda bilder och klipp ur filmen i min artikel som publiceras på nätet?

– I upphovsrättslagen finns det ett undantag som handlar om recensioner eller ”kritisk framställning” som det kallas för i lagen. Genom den bestämmelsen kan det möjligen vara tillåtet att använda bild ur exempelvis en film i en recension om filmen som du har skrivit. Men, det gäller bara i tryckt form, dvs. inte i digital form. Det innebär att om du skriver en filmrecension som du publicerar på nätet och vill använda bild från filmen så kan du behöva tillstånd. Samtidigt kan det vara så att filmbolaget som har lanserat filmen har lagt upp särskilda s k ”pressbilder” på sin webbsida som får användas när media skriver om filmen. Kanske kan det även gälla för din recensionsartikel.

Får jag ta en egen bild på ett bokomslag eller filmaffisch och använda i min artikel?

- Att ta en bild på ett bokomslag eller filmaffisch och använda i en recension av boken eller filmen är tillåtet så länge recensionen publiceras i tryckt form, alltså i pappersform. Däremot behövs det tillstånd från illustratören eller fotografen som gjort bokomslaget om recensionen ska publiceras digitalt. Detsamma gäller filmaffischen. Vänd dig i så fall till filmbolaget och fråga om tillstånd. Tillstånd behövs däremot inte om du istället väljer att lägga in en hyperlänk i din recension till en officiell webbsida där bokomslaget eller filmaffischen redan finns. Det innebär inte att bilden får läggas in i den digitala recensionen, men länken kan då bli kopplingen till boken eller filmen som du recenserar.

Var kan elever själva hitta mer information om upphovsrätt?

- Det finns mycket information om upphovsrätt att hitta på nätet, men en hel del kan vara vinklad och det förekommer ibland information som är direkt felaktig. På www.prv.se/upphovsratt får du svar på många av de vanligaste frågorna om upphovsrätt. Vill du lära dig om upphovsrätt på ett kul sätt, gå in på www.upphovsrättsskolan.se och snurra lyckohjulet, leta efter copyrighttecken eller spela memoryspelet!

DETTA ÄR PATENT- OCH REGISTRERINGSVERKET

Patent- och registreringsverket förkortas PRV och är en svensk statlig myndighet som ansvarar för immaterialrätt. Myndighetens uppdrag är att stimulera innovationer och entreprenörskap genom att bland annat registrera patent, design- och varumärken som någon söker skydd för. I uppdraget ingår också att öka kunskapen om upphovsrätt (som är en del av immaterialrätten), både hos upphovspersonerna själva och hos allmänheten generellt. Läs mer på om detta på myndighetens hemsida: https://www.prv.se/sv/om-oss/

Av: Jenny Sköld

Senast uppdaterad: 22.10.03

Källor: (1) Catharina Ekdahl, Catharina Ekdahl är jurist på PRV och projektledare för Upphovsrättsskolan.se

node.Title: Så fixar du personporträttet!
node.Body:
I personporträttet försöker journalisten få läsarna att komma så nära en viss person som möjligt, och texten är därför mycket mer personlig än nyhetsartikeln eller även reportaget.

Samtidigt får man inte glömma att även ett personporträtt är en faktatext. Den som bara återger vad den intervjuade personen säger, skriver snarare en självbiografi. Intervjuerna är till för att ge plats för den person man skriver om att ge sin syn på saken, men det måste alltid backas upp med sedvanlig faktagranskning och källkritik. Därför är det också mycket viktigt att göra en ordentlig research, bakgrundsundersökning, helst före intervjun. Då blir det lättare att ta fram frågor, ställa följdfrågor och avgöra om personen kanske minns fel eller förvanskar sanningen. 

Eftersom ett personporträtt ofta kommer ganska nära personen måste journalisten hantera texten med stor hänsyn och respekt för integriteten hos den person som porträtteras. Har man exempelvis fått fram något missaktande eller negativt i sin research och vill ha med det i texten, måste personen få veta det i samband med intervjun. I och med att det är en faktatext bör det ges utrymme för personen att bemöta det negativa och ge sin syn på saken.

Personporträttet är i övrigt uppbyggt på samma sätt som andra faktatexter, med rubrik, ingress, brödtext och bildtexter. Skillnaden är den personliga vinkeln och att man i större grad citerar, återger vad någon säger. Glöm inte de att försöka besvara de sex journalistiska frågeorden: var, när, hur, vem, vad och varför!

Rubriken har som alltid till uppgift att vara intressant och locka till läsning, men samtidigt att vara sann och stämma överens med texten i övrigt. Man kan försöka hitta en rubrik som sammanfattar hela texten men också anger den personliga tonen.

Exempel: Från division 3 till Elitettan: trots allvarlig sjukdom lyfte Lotta laget

Ingressen kan användas även för personporträtten, den ska inleda texten och bör vara kort. Eftersom texten kommer att fokusera på en person, bör även ingressen göra det och med samma vinkel. Besvara gärna någon av de journalistiska frågorna i ingressen, och försök få med ett citat.

Exempel: På bara tre år har tränaren Lotta Stenhård lyft Trädgården BK från ett fotbollslag i glömska till en framgångssaga med sikte på Allsvenskan. Men Lotta låter sig inte nöjas med det.

– Vi ska med i Champions League, och vinna, säger den självsäkra tränaren. Men den självsäkerheten är ny hos Lotta, som har fått jobba hårt för att ta sig fram.

Brödtexten i ett personporträtt fokuserar naturligtvis på den som texten handlar om. Därför innehåller texten oftast många fler citat än övriga texter. Vanligtvis skrivs även journalistens frågor ut, så att texten nästan blir som ett samtal. Men det kan heller inte bli enbart en berättande text. Eftersom den ska bygga på fakta, som journalisten har granskat och läst på före intervjun, måste det också ges utrymme. Det är med fakta som journalisten för berättelsen framåt, och med intervjuer som man ger förklaringar och beskrivningar.

Exempel: När Lotta Stenhård värvades till Trädgården BK hade laget spelat i division 3 i fyra år, och till och med varit nära att ramla ur divisionen. Efter bara ett år hade den nya tränaren inte bara lyft laget, utan ocksåflyttat upp dem till division 2. Men succén var långt ifrån säker:

– Vi drabbades av flera skador det året, särskilt Jennys ledbandsskada gjorde vårt försvar svagt. Till slut var det bara med ett poäng tillgodo vigick vidare. Det var en nervös höst, säger Lotta som nu ler åt det. Detvar också samma höst hon fick beskedet om sin sjukdom.

– Ja, fy! Det önskar jag ingen.

Ett bra sätt att ge en mer nyanserad bild av personen man ska porträttera är att även intervjua andra människor i närheten, som kollegor, familj och vänner. Som journalist gäller det att respektera integriteten hos och visa hänsyn till huvudpersonen. Man kan vara öppen med vilka man ska intervjua och vad man kommer att skriva, det kan ju hända att personen som ska porträtteras måste få kommentera något som sagts om hen. Den slutgiltiga texten är det dock alltid journalisten som bestämmer över och får ansvara för.

Det är lätt för journalisten att falla i fällan att börja skriva om sig själv i stället för om den som ska porträtteras. Stycken som handlar om hur journalisten kände sig under intervjun, eller egna erfarenheter och upplevelser hör inte hemma i en text som handlar om någon annan. Visst kan journalisten tillåta sig att finnas med i texten, men då i begränsad omfattning.

Mellanrubriker, mellisar, fungerar även i personporträtt men är kanske inte lika nödvändiga som i andra faktatexter. Det kan dock vara en god idé att använda dem, då mellisar lättar upp den tryckta texten som blir luftigare och mer lättläst. De kan också hjälpa läsaren att orientera sig i texten och locka till vidare läsning.

Bildtexter används även i personporträtt, liksom i övriga journalistiska texter. Som vanligt ska de inte bara återge det vi ser i bilden, utan tillföra någon information. Eftersom personporträttet ska ge läsaren en närmare bild och förståelse för någon, kan exempelvis ett citat eller en beskrivande förklaring användas som bildtext.

Exempel: (Bild på fotbollstränaren Lotta Stenhård som tittar ut genom kontorsfönstret.)

– Vi ska spela mot de bästa i Europa, säger Lotta bestämt.

Faktarutan är ett bra sätt att samla information och fakta kring den man porträtterar, utan att tynga ned brödtexten för mycket. I en avgränsad ruta kan man ange sådant som är viktigt för personporträttet som bakgrund, utbildning, yrke men även mer personliga saker som musiksmak, favoritmat och var personen helst firar semester kan finnas med i en faktaruta.

Avslutningen på ett personporträtt kan ges en lite mer personlig känsla som går i samma stil som den övriga texten. Den man skriver om kanske får avsluta med att fundera på framtiden i ett citat.

– Man måste se framåt, säger Lotta, och nu när jag är frisk igen kommer fokus vara att vinna Allsvenskan.

Texten är hämtad ur Mediekompass och Statens medieråds gemensamma material Publicistguiden.

node.Body:
Här väljer du den arbetsgrupp du tillhör. Medlemmar i samma arbetsgrupp kan bjuda in varandra och samarbeta i artiklar. Du som har skapat artikeln kan välja vilka andra i gruppen som kan redigera artikeln och vilka som kan kamratgranska.
